docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will help you get started with CPH-NG in minutes. For detailed information about all features, see the Feature Guide.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
First, the CPH-NG VS Code extension must be installed in your environment. You can install it directly by clicking this link: Install CPH-NG. Please ensure you have the latest version installed.

After installation, you'll find the extension's sidebar icon on the left side of your VS Code window. Feel free to drag it to the right side if you prefer.

!!! tip "First Time Setup" Before creating your first problem, you may want to configure compiler settings in Configuration.

docs.title: Create a problem
docs.text: A problem would be created after you click the CREATE button. You can do this by using the command CPH-NG: Create Problem or pressing Ctrl+Alt+B as a shortcut.

docs.title: Add test cases
docs.text:
Once the problem is created,the buttons below are able to be used.

The leftmost button is used to create a single test case. You will need to manually enter the input data and the expected answer (output).

  • Tip: CPH-NG also supports loading test cases from zipped files or specific directories, which is a great option for managing large datasets.

docs.title: Run test cases
docs.text:
• To run a single test case, click the green play button next to that test case.

  • To run all test cases simultaneously, click the middle play button in the lower control panel.

CPH-NG would show you the first judged test case which isn't accepted automatically.

If you load these test cases from files,the output would be also showed as files.Drag or click them to show them in detailed.

Now, you have already learned the basic usage of CPH-NG. Enjoy coding with CPH-NG!

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore all features in the Feature Guide
  • Learn about Configuration Options
  • Check Modules for additional functionality
  • Visit FAQ if you have questions

docs.title: Basic Settings
docs.text: General settings that control UI behavior and folder selection methods.

docs.title: cph-ng.basic.folderOpener
docs.text:
Controls which method is used for selecting folders in dialogs.

  • Type: String enum ("default" | "native")
  • Default: "default"
  • User Impact:
    • "default": Uses VS Code's standard folder picker (works in all environments including remote development)
    • "native": Uses system native folder dialog (may provide better UX on local systems but doesn't work in remote/web environments)

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.basic.folderOpener": "native"
}

When loading test cases from a folder, the system's native folder picker will be used instead of VS Code's dialog.

docs.title: When to Change This Setting
docs.text:
• Use "default": If you work with remote development (SSH, WSL, containers), or experience issues with folder selection
  • Use "native": If you prefer your operating system's folder picker and work only on local files

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text: • Load Test Cases - Uses folder selection when loading from folders

docs.title: Brute Force Compare Settings
docs.text: Settings for the brute force comparison feature that automatically finds failing test cases.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Brute force comparison helps you find edge cases by:

  1. Running a generator to create random inputs
  2. Running your solution on those inputs
  3. Running a known-correct brute force solution
  4. Comparing outputs to find discrepancies

docs.title: cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit
docs.text:
Maximum time (in milliseconds) allowed for the test case generator to run.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 3000 (3 seconds)
  • User Impact: If the generator takes longer than this to produce a test case, it will be terminated. Increase if your generator needs more time for complex test cases.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 5000
}

Allow generator up to 5 seconds to create each test case.

docs.title: cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit
docs.text:
Maximum time (in milliseconds) allowed for the brute force solution to run.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 10000 (10 seconds)
  • User Impact: If the brute force solution takes longer than this, it will be terminated. Brute force solutions are often slow, so this is typically higher than normal time limits.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 30000
}

Allow brute force solution up to 30 seconds per test case.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Generator Execution: Creates a random test input (limited by generatorTimeLimit)
  2. Your Solution: Runs on the generated input (uses problem's time limit)
  3. Brute Force Solution: Runs on the same input (limited by bruteForceTimeLimit)
  4. Comparison: Outputs are compared
  5. Result:
    • If outputs match: Try another test case
    • If outputs differ: Found failing case! Saved for debugging

docs.title: Disk Operations
docs.text:
When a failing test case is found:

  1. Input Saved: Generated input is saved to disk as a new test case
  2. Your Output: Your solution's output is recorded
  3. Expected Output: Brute force solution's output becomes the expected answer
  4. Problem Updated: New test case is added to the problem file
  5. Files Updated: Problem data file (.cph-ng/*.bin) is updated with the new test case

docs.title: When to Adjust These Settings
docs.text:
Increase generatorTimeLimit when:

  • Generator creates complex structures (graphs, trees)
  • Generator validates constraints
  • Getting timeout errors during generation

Increase bruteForceTimeLimit when:

  • Brute force solution has high complexity (O(n³), O(2ⁿ))
  • Testing with large inputs
  • Getting timeout on correct brute force solutions

Decrease timeouts when:

  • Want faster iteration (test more cases per minute)
  • Generator and brute force are very fast
  • Working with small inputs

docs.title: For Simple Problems
docs.text:
{
    "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 1000,
    "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 5000
}

docs.title: For Complex Problems
docs.text:
{
    "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 10000,
    "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 60000
}

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Brute Force Compare - Main feature documentation
  • Add Test Case - Where found cases are saved
  • Runner Settings - Your solution uses standard runner settings

docs.title: Cache Settings
docs.text: Settings that control compilation caching to speed up repeated compilations.

docs.title: cph-ng.cache.cacheDirectory
docs.text:
Location where compilation cache files are stored.

  • Type: String (path template)
  • Default: "${tmp}/cph-ng"
  • User Impact: Determines where compiled binaries and cache data are stored on disk. Changing this affects:
    • Disk space usage location
    • Cache persistence across sessions
    • Multi-workspace cache sharing

Path Variables:

Variable Description ${tmp} System temporary directory ${workspace} Workspace root directory ${home} User home directory

Examples:

{
    "cph-ng.cache.cacheDirectory": "${workspace}/.cache/cph-ng"
}

Stores cache in workspace (persists with project, not shared between projects).

{
    "cph-ng.cache.cacheDirectory": "${home}/.cache/cph-ng"
}

Stores cache in home directory (shared between all projects, persists after closing VS Code).

docs.title: cph-ng.cache.cleanOnStartup
docs.text:
Automatically clean cache directory when VS Code starts.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
    • false: Cache persists between sessions (faster first compilation)
    • true: Cache is cleared on startup (ensures fresh compilation, uses more disk space temporarily)

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.cache.cleanOnStartup": true
}

Cache is cleared every time you start VS Code.

docs.title: Compilation Cache
docs.text:
When you compile a program:

  1. Hash Calculation: CPH-NG calculates a hash based on:
    • Source code content
    • Compiler path and arguments
    • Compilation settings

  2. Cache Check: Looks for cached binary with matching hash

  3. Cache Hit: If found, reuses compiled binary (skip compilation)

  4. Cache Miss: Compiles and stores binary in cache with hash

  5. Cache Location: Binary saved to ${cacheDirectory}/${hash}.o

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• Faster Testing: No recompilation when source hasn't changed
  • Quick Retries: Rerunning same tests is instant
  • Lower CPU Usage: Less compilation overhead

docs.title: Disk Usage
docs.text:
Each unique compilation creates a cached binary file:

  • Typical Size: 100KB - 5MB per binary (depends on source code size and compilation flags)
  • Growth: Cache grows as you work on different problems and make changes
  • Cleanup: Automatically cleaned if cleanOnStartup is true, or manually delete the cache directory

docs.title: When to Change These Settings
docs.text:
Change cacheDirectory when:

  • Want cache to persist with project (use ${workspace}/.cache)
  • Want cache shared globally (use ${home}/.cache)
  • Using remote development (use location accessible in remote environment)
  • Need to control disk usage location

Enable cleanOnStartup when:

  • Experiencing compilation issues
  • Disk space is limited
  • Want to ensure fresh compilation every session
  • Debugging compilation problems

Keep cleanOnStartup false when:

  • Want maximum performance
  • Have plenty of disk space
  • Frequently recompile same code

docs.title: Manual Cache Cleanup
docs.text:
You can manually clean the cache by deleting the cache directory:

Linux/macOS:

rm -rf /tmp/cph-ng

Windows:

rd /s /q %TEMP%\cph-ng

Or use the location specified in your cacheDirectory setting.

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Compilation Settings - Compiler settings affect cache hash
  • Run Single Test - Benefits from caching
  • Run All Tests - Only compiles once due to caching

docs.title: Competitive Companion Settings
docs.text: Settings for integration with the Competitive Companion browser extension.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Competitive Companion is a browser extension that can automatically send problem information from online judges (Codeforces, AtCoder, etc.) directly to CPH-NG.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.listenPort
docs.text:
Port number CPH-NG listens on for Competitive Companion connections.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 10046
  • User Impact: This must match the port configured in your Competitive Companion browser extension. If you change this, update the extension settings too.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.listenPort": 10050
}

Change if port 10046 is already in use by another application.

!!! warning "Port Conflicts" If another application uses this port, Competitive Companion won't work. Change to an available port (1024-65535).

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.defaultExtension
docs.text:
Default file extension for problems imported from Competitive Companion.

  • Type: String
  • Default: ".cpp"
  • User Impact: When importing a problem, a new file with this extension is automatically created if it doesn't exist.

Options:

  • ".cpp" - C++
  • ".c" - C
  • ".java" - Java

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.defaultExtension": ".java"
}

Problems imported from browser will create .java files.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.chooseSaveFolder
docs.text:
Prompt for save location when importing problems.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
    • false: Problems saved to current workspace automatically
    • true: You're prompted to choose save location for each problem

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.chooseSaveFolder": true
}

You'll be asked where to save each imported problem.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.addTimestamp
docs.text:
Add timestamp to filenames when importing problems.

  • Type: Number (enum: 0, 1, 2)
  • Default: 0

  • Values:

    • 0: No timestamp
    • 1: Add timestamp if file exists
    • 2: Always add timestamp

  • User Impact: Controls filename collision handling:

    • 0: A.cpp (overwrites if exists)
    • 1: A.cpp first time, A-1234567890.cpp if exists
    • 2: A-1234567890.cpp always

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.addTimestamp": 1
}

Adds timestamp only when filename conflicts occur.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName
docs.text:
Use shorter names for Codeforces problems.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
    • false: Uses full names like Codeforces Round 123 - Problem A - Title
    • true: Uses short names like A or 123A

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName": true
}

Imported Codeforces problems get short names: A.cpp, B.cpp, etc.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortLuoguName
docs.text:
Use shorter names for Luogu problems.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact: Similar to Codeforces, controls whether to use full problem titles or short identifiers.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.shortLuoguName": true
}

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortAtCoderName
docs.text:
Use shorter names for AtCoder problems.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact: Similar to Codeforces, controls whether to use full problem titles or short identifiers.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.shortAtCoderName": true
}

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.showPanel
docs.text:
Control visibility of problem source file when importing.

  • Type: Number (enum: 0, 1, 2)
  • Default: 2

  • Values:

    • 0: Never show source file
    • 1: Show only if file is new
    • 2: Always show source file

  • User Impact: Controls whether the imported source file opens in editor:

    • 0: File created but not opened
    • 1: Opens only newly created files
    • 2: Always opens the file

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.showPanel": 0
}

Files are created but not automatically opened in editor.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.submitLanguage
docs.text:
Default language ID for submissions to online judges.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 54 (C++17 GCC)
  • User Impact: When submitting to Codeforces or other judges, this language is selected by default. Language IDs vary by platform.

Common Language IDs (Codeforces):

  • 43: GNU G++17 7.3.0
  • 54: GNU G++17 9.2.0
  • 73: GNU G++20 11.2.0
  • 87: GNU G++20 13.2.0

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.companion.submitLanguage": 73
}

Use C++20 (GCC 11) for submissions.

!!! tip "Finding Language IDs" Check the language dropdown on the judge's submission page to find the correct ID for your preferred language and compiler version.

docs.title: Codeforces Competitive Setup
docs.text:
{
    "cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName": true,
    "cph-ng.companion.addTimestamp": 0,
    "cph-ng.companion.showPanel": 2,
    "cph-ng.companion.submitLanguage": 73
}

docs.title: Multi-Judge Setup
docs.text:
{
    "cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName": true,
    "cph-ng.companion.shortAtCoderName": true,
    "cph-ng.companion.shortLuoguName": true,
    "cph-ng.companion.chooseSaveFolder": true
}

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
When you click Competitive Companion in your browser:

  1. Extension Connects: Browser extension connects to localhost:10046 (or your configured port)
  2. Data Sent: Problem metadata and test cases sent to CPH-NG
  3. File Created: Source file created with defaultExtension in chosen/current location
  4. Naming Applied: Filename determined by platform-specific naming settings
  5. Problem Initialized: Problem structure created with received test cases
  6. Disk Operations:
    • Source file written: ${workspace}/${problemName}.cpp
    • Problem data written: ${workspace}/.cph-ng/${problemName}.cpp.bin
  7. UI Update: Problem panel shown based on showPanel setting

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Competitive Companion - How to use the integration
  • Import Problem - Manual import alternative
  • Submit to Codeforces - Uses submitLanguage setting

docs.title: Comparing Settings
docs.text: Settings that control how test outputs are compared against expected answers.

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.oleSize
docs.text:
Threshold (in lines) for Output Limit Exceeded detection.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 3
  • User Impact: If actual output has more than this many extra lines compared to expected answer, verdict becomes OLE (Output Limit Exceeded) instead of WA (Wrong Answer).

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.comparing.oleSize": 5
}

Output with 6+ extra lines gets OLE instead of WA.

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC
docs.text:
Treat Presentation Error (trailing/leading whitespace differences) as Accepted.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
    • false: Extra whitespace at line ends or extra blank lines causes PE verdict
    • true: Whitespace differences are ignored, verdict becomes AC

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC": true
}

Trailing spaces and extra blank lines don't cause PE verdict.

!!! tip "Competitive Programming" Most online judges are lenient with whitespace. Setting this to true matches typical judge behavior.

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError
docs.text:
Controls whether stderr output is considered in verdict.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • User Impact:
    • true: Programs can write to stderr without affecting verdict (common for debug output)
    • false: Any stderr output causes different verdict or warning

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError": false
}

Programs writing to stderr will be flagged.

!!! note "Debug Output" Keeping this true allows using cerr for debugging in C++ without affecting correctness checks.

docs.title: Comparison Behavior
docs.text:
The comparison process works as follows:

  1. Exact Match: Output matches answer exactly → AC (Accepted)
  2. Whitespace Differences: Trailing/leading spaces differ → PE (Presentation Error), or AC if regardPEAsAC is true
  3. Wrong Content: Output content differs → WA (Wrong Answer)
  4. Too Much Output: More than oleSize extra lines → OLE (Output Limit Exceeded)
  5. Runtime Error: Program crashes or returns non-zero exit code → RE (Runtime Error)
  6. Time Limit: Execution exceeds time limit → TLE (Time Limit Exceeded)
  7. Memory Limit: Memory usage exceeds limit (if runner enabled) → MLE (Memory Limit Exceeded)

docs.title: When to Change These Settings
docs.text:
Set regardPEAsAC to true:

  • Preparing for online judges that ignore whitespace
  • Don't want to worry about output formatting
  • Focus on algorithm correctness

Set regardPEAsAC to false:

  • Need exact output format matching
  • Testing output formatting requirements
  • Preparing for strict formatting contests

Set ignoreError to false:

  • Debugging programs that shouldn't write to stderr
  • Want to catch all diagnostic output
  • Testing code quality

Adjust oleSize:

  • Getting incorrect OLE verdicts
  • Want stricter or more lenient detection

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Compare Output - Visual diff for WA/PE cases
  • Run Single Test - Uses these comparison rules
  • Run All Tests - Applies to all test comparisons
  • Special Judge - Overrides standard comparison

docs.title: Compilation Settings
docs.text: Settings that control how CPH-NG compiles your source code for C, C++, and Java.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cPath
docs.text:
Path to the C compiler executable.

  • Type: String (executable path)
  • Default: "gcc"
  • User Impact: Specifies which C compiler to use. Must be accessible in your system PATH or provide full path.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.cPath": "/usr/bin/clang"
}

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cppPath
docs.text:
Path to the C++ compiler executable.

  • Type: String (executable path)
  • Default: "g++"
  • User Impact: Specifies which C++ compiler to use. Must be accessible in your system PATH or provide full path.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.cppPath": "/usr/bin/clang++"
}

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.javaPath
docs.text:
Path to the Java compiler executable.

  • Type: String (executable path)
  • Default: "javac"
  • User Impact: Specifies which Java compiler to use. Must be accessible in your system PATH or provide full path.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.javaPath": "/usr/lib/jvm/java-17/bin/javac"
}

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cArgs
docs.text:
Additional arguments passed to the C compiler.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "-O2 -std=gnu11 -Wall"
  • User Impact: Controls optimization level, language standard, and warnings. Common use cases:
    • Optimization: -O0 (debug), -O2 (standard), -O3 (aggressive)
    • Standards: -std=c11, -std=c17, -std=gnu11
    • Warnings: -Wall, -Wextra, -Werror
    • Debugging: -g
    • Sanitizers: -fsanitize=address, -fsanitize=undefined

Examples:

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.cArgs": "-O3 -std=c17 -Wall -Wextra"
}

Use C17 standard with aggressive optimization and extra warnings.

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.cArgs": "-g -O0 -std=c11 -Wall -fsanitize=address"
}

Debug configuration with address sanitizer to catch memory errors.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs
docs.text:
Additional arguments passed to the C++ compiler.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "-O2 -std=gnu++17 -Wall"
  • User Impact: Controls C++ compilation. Common use cases:
    • Standards: -std=c++11, -std=c++14, -std=c++17, -std=c++20, -std=gnu++17
    • Optimizations: Same as C
    • Debugging: -g, -fsanitize=address, -fsanitize=undefined
    • Platform: -m32 (32-bit), -m64 (64-bit)

Examples:

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-O2 -std=c++20 -Wall"
}

Use C++20 standard with O2 optimization for competitive programming.

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-g -O0 -std=c++17 -Wall -fsanitize=address,undefined"
}

Debug with multiple sanitizers to catch memory and undefined behavior errors.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.javaArgs
docs.text:
Additional arguments passed to the Java compiler.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "-encoding UTF-8"
  • User Impact: Controls Java compilation options.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.javaArgs": "-encoding UTF-8 -Xlint:all"
}

Enable all compiler warnings.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.timeout
docs.text:
Maximum time allowed for compilation (in milliseconds).

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 3000 (3 seconds)
  • User Impact: If compilation takes longer than this, it will be terminated. Increase if you have large projects or slower systems.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.timeout": 10000
}

Allow up to 10 seconds for compilation.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.wrapper
docs.text:
Command wrapper that executes before the compiler.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "" (empty)
  • User Impact: Runs before compilation. Use cases:
    • Environment setup
    • Custom build scripts
    • Compiler selection based on conditions

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.compilation.wrapper": "ccache"
}

Use ccache to speed up recompilation.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.beforeCompileHook
docs.text:
Command executed before compilation starts.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "" (empty)
  • User Impact: Runs as a separate command before compilation. Use cases:
    • Pre-processing source files
    • Generating code
    • Checking dependencies

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.afterCompileHook
docs.text:
Command executed after compilation completes.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "" (empty)
  • User Impact: Runs after successful compilation. Use cases:
    • Post-processing binaries
    • Running static analyzers
    • Copying output files

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run Single Test - Compiles before running
  • Run All Tests - Compiles once for all tests
  • Cache Settings - Affects compilation speed through caching

docs.title: CPH Compatibility Settings
docs.text: Settings that control integration with the original CPH (Competitive Programming Helper) extension.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: CPH-NG can import problems created with the original CPH extension, allowing you to migrate existing problems or use both extensions in parallel.

docs.title: cph-ng.cphCapable.checkOnStartup
docs.text:
Automatically check for CPH problems when opening files.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • User Impact:
    • true: CPH-NG detects when you open a file with existing CPH data and offers to import it
    • false: No automatic detection; manual import only

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.cphCapable.checkOnStartup": false
}

Disable automatic CPH problem detection.

docs.title: cph-ng.cphCapable.checkInterval
docs.text:
How often to check for CPH problems (in milliseconds).

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 5000 (5 seconds)
  • User Impact: Controls the delay between checks when opening files. Lower values mean faster detection but slightly more resource usage.

Example:

{
    "cph-ng.cphCapable.checkInterval": 10000
}

Check for CPH problems every 10 seconds.

docs.title: Detection Process
docs.text:
1. File Open: When you open a source file (.cpp, .c, .java)
  2. CPH Check: CPH-NG looks for .cph/ folder in the workspace
  3. Problem Match: Searches for matching problem file (.cph/.{filename}.prob)
  4. Import Prompt: If found and not already imported, shows import button

docs.title: Import Process
docs.text:
When you click the import button:

  1. Read CPH Data: Reads problem metadata from .cph/.{filename}.prob
  2. Convert Format: Transforms CPH format to CPH-NG format
  3. Create Problem: Creates CPH-NG problem structure
  4. Save Data: Writes to .cph-ng/{filename}.bin
  5. Preserve Original: Original CPH .prob file remains unchanged

docs.title: File Structure
docs.text:
Original CPH:

workspace/
├── problem.cpp
└── .cph/
    └── .problem.cpp.prob  (CPH format - JSON)

After CPH-NG Import:

workspace/
├── problem.cpp
├── .cph/
│   └── .problem.cpp.prob  (Original CPH - preserved)
└── .cph-ng/
    └── problem.cpp.bin    (CPH-NG format - compressed)

docs.title: Data Migration
docs.text:
CPH-NG imports the following from CPH:

  • ✅ Problem name
  • ✅ Test cases (input and expected output)
  • ✅ Time limit
  • ✅ Memory limit
  • ✅ Source file path
  • ❌ Custom checkers (not supported in CPH)
  • ❌ Interactive problems (not supported in CPH)

docs.title: When to Change These Settings
docs.text:
Disable checkOnStartup when:

  • Not using original CPH extension
  • Don't want automatic detection
  • Performance concerns
  • Want to manually control imports

Increase checkInterval when:

  • Experiencing performance issues
  • Don't need immediate detection
  • Working with many files

Keep Default Settings when:

  • Migrating from CPH to CPH-NG
  • Using both extensions simultaneously
  • Want seamless import experience

docs.title: One-Time Migration
docs.text:
If migrating all problems from CPH to CPH-NG:

  1. Keep checkOnStartup: true
  2. Open each file with CPH problems
  3. Click import button when prompted
  4. After all imported, set checkOnStartup: false to disable checks

docs.title: Parallel Usage
docs.text:
If using both CPH and CPH-NG:

  1. Keep checkOnStartup: true
  2. CPH-NG will detect and import new CPH problems automatically
  3. Both extensions can work on different problems
  4. Each has its own data folder (.cph vs .cph-ng)

docs.title: Import Button Not Showing
docs.text:
Possible causes:

  • checkOnStartup is false → Enable it
  • No .cph/ folder in workspace → Verify CPH problems exist
  • Problem already imported → Check .cph-ng/ folder
  • File not active → Make sure file is open in editor

Solution:

  • Enable checkOnStartup
  • Use "CPH-NG: Import from CPH" command manually

docs.title: Import Fails
docs.text:
Possible causes:

  • Corrupted .prob file
  • Incompatible CPH version
  • File permission issues

Solution:

  • Check .prob file is valid JSON
  • Manually create problem in CPH-NG
  • Check file permissions

docs.title: Manual Import
docs.text:
You can always manually import using command palette:

  1. Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+P (macOS)
  2. Type and select: CPH-NG: Import from CPH
  3. Select problems to import

This works regardless of checkOnStartup setting.

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• CPH Import - Detailed import process
  • Create Problem - Alternative to importing
  • Import Problem - Import from CPH-NG format

docs.title: Configuration Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for all CPH-NG configuration settings, organized by category.

docs.title: Setting Categories
docs.text: CPH-NG provides 10 categories of settings to customize behavior:

docs.title: 1. Basic Settings

General extension behavior and UI preferences.

Key Settings:

  • Folder selection method

docs.title: 3. Runner Settings

docs.title: 4. Comparing Settings

Output comparison and verdict determination.

docs.title: 5. Brute Force Compare Settings

Settings for brute force comparison feature.

docs.title: 6. Problem Settings

Problem file management and defaults.

docs.title: 7. Cache Settings

Compilation cache and temporary files.

UI customization for the CPH-NG panel.

Key Settings:

Related Features: All features (affects UI display)

docs.title: Path Variables
docs.text:
Many settings support template variables for flexible path configuration:

Variable Description Example ${workspace} Workspace root /home/user/project ${tmp} System temp directory /tmp ${home} User home directory /home/user ${dirname} File directory /home/user/project/src ${relativeDirname} Relative directory src ${basename} Filename with extension main.cpp ${basenameNoExt} Filename without extension main ${extname} File extension .cpp

docs.title: Settings Access
docs.text:
VS Code UI:

  1. Press Ctrl+, (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+, (macOS)
  2. Search for "cph-ng"
  3. Browse and modify settings

settings.json:

{
    "cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit": 2000,
    "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-O2 -std=c++20 -Wall"
}

docs.title: Competitive Programming Setup
docs.text:
{
    "cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit": 2000,
    "cph-ng.problem.defaultMemoryLimit": 256,
    "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-O2 -std=c++17 -Wall",
    "cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName": true,
    "cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC": false
}

docs.title: Debug Configuration
docs.text:
{
    "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-g -O0 -std=c++20 -Wall -fsanitize=address",
    "cph-ng.runner.useRunner": true,
    "cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError": false
}

docs.title: Performance Optimization
docs.text:
{
    "cph-ng.cache.cleanOnStartup": false,
    "cph-ng.compilation.timeout": 5000,
    "cph-ng.runner.timeAddition": 500
}

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Click any category above to view detailed settings documentation with:

  • Setting descriptions and types
  • Default values

  • Related features

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check FAQ for common questions
  • See Quick Start for basic setup
